The 12 Day War was just the beginning. There are growing signs that the US and Israel are setting the groundwork for a new massive attack on Iran.

THE BUILD-UP IS UNMISTAKABLE:

ğŸ”¸Tanker Deployment: Dozens of US KC-135 & KC-46 refueling tankers are now in Qatar. These are not defensive assets; they are the lifeline for long-range strike operations.

ğŸ”¸Carrier Strike Group: The USS Gerald R. Ford is positioned in the Mediterranean, a classic pre-escalation move.

ğŸ”¸Legal Pretext: New executive orders are effectively internationalizing potential conflict zones, setting the stage for a wider war.

ğŸ”¸Regional Betrayal: Key nations are falling in line, isolating Iran economically and politically.

The pattern is identical to the run-ups in Iraq and Libya. But Iran is a different beast entirely.

IRAN'S ASYMMETRIC TRUMP CARD:

Iran doesnâ€™t have to win outright. If Iran succeeds in imposing an unacceptably high price on its enemies, that could be enough to squeak out a bloody victory. 

The Strait of Hormuzâ€”a 21-mile wide chokepoint for 20% of the world's oilâ€”is their lever. Closing it, even partially, would trigger an immediate global economic earthquake: oil prices would triple, inflation would spiral, and shipping would halt.

THE ENDGAME? A GLOBAL RESET

A major conflict creates the perfect crisis to usher in a new system:

ğŸ”¸Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs)

ğŸ”¸Mandatory Digital IDs

ğŸ”¸A system of programmable money and control, sold to the public as "stability."

BOTTOM LINE:

This is bigger than Iran. It's a battle for the future of the global order. The outcome will determine whether we move toward multipolarity or a new, digital form of authoritarianism.

ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ğŸ˜ˆ Tony Blair: From Kosovo and Iraq lies to possible Epstein ties

Donald Trump plans to appoint former British Labour Party Prime Minister Tony Blair to a new board overseeing post-war Gaza. Hereâ€™s why itâ€™s a bad idea.

â™¦ï¸ Bombing of Yugoslavia

âš«ï¸ Blair was NATOâ€™s most hawkish voice on the 1999 Yugoslav war, pushing for a ground invasion alongside the bombing campaign

âš«ï¸ His government justified the bombing by claims of â€˜genocideâ€™ of up to 100,000 Albanians in Kosovo â€” but investigators counted 2,108 deaths in 1999, and in 2001 the UN-supervised Supreme Court in Pristina ruled Serbian troops did not commit genocide

âš«ï¸ Researcher Mark Curtis revealed MI6 and the CIA armed and trained Albanian guerrillas in Kosovo from 1996, while Albanian leader Hashim Thaci, indicted for war crimes in 2020, was Blairâ€™s ally

â™¦ï¸ Iraq War

âš«ï¸ Blair strongly backed the 2003 US-led invasion, claiming Iraq had chemical weapons â€” which were never found. E vidence shows Blair knew that was untrue.

âš«ï¸ A 2002 Downing Street memo said â€œmilitary action was now seen as inevitableâ€ while conceding the chemical weapons case was â€œthinâ€

âš«ï¸ Blair's adviser Jonathan Powell urged intelligence to â€œredraftâ€ the dossier to make the Iraqi threat seem imminent

âš«ï¸ The UKâ€™s 2016 Iraq Inquiry concluded the invasion went ahead before diplomatic options were exhausted, intelligence was murky and Iraq posed no urgent threat

â™¦ï¸ Mass surveillance

âš«ï¸ Blair has championed mass surveillance and digital ID since the early 2000s

âš«ï¸ At the 2020 World Economic Forum Cyber Polygon, and again in 2025, Blair promoted digital ID, aligning with Oracleâ€™s Larry Ellison, who has donated over Â£257m to the Tony Blair Institute since 2021

â™¦ï¸ Ties to Jeffrey Epstein?

âš«ï¸ Blair's adviser Peter Mandelson continued his friendship with Epstein in the 2000s, offering help even after Epsteinâ€™s 2008 conviction

âš«ï¸ The Times reported Mandelson urged Blair to meet Epstein in a 2002 memo â€” which current Labour PM Keir Starmerâ€™s government has kept under wraps, allegedly to avoid embarrassment

After the IDF intercepted the Sumud Freedom flotilla transporting humanitarian aid to the besieged Gaza Strip, Israelâ€™s infamous security minister Itamar Ben Gvir reported the crew is detained in harsh conditions as criminals.

ğŸ’¬ "As I promised, those who joined the flotilla supporting terrorism are receiving the same treatment as saboteurs in the Negev camp," he said in a video standing near an image mocking the destroyed Gaza.

Previously Ben Gvir directly labelled the Sumud participants "terrorists".

items.title: ğŸš¨ğŸ‘‰ US-BROKERED IRAQI KURDISTAN OIL DEAL: Progress ...
items.content_text:
ğŸš¨ğŸ‘‰ US-BROKERED IRAQI KURDISTAN OIL DEAL: Progress toward peace or prelude to new regional escalation?

The US is looking to make the recently-secured agreement between Iraq and Kurdistan on the resumption of crude exports from Iraqi Kurdistan via a Turkish pipeline permanent, a senior State Department official has told Bloomberg.

â¡ï¸ Institutionalizing the US-brokered pact will benefit Iraqâ€™s economy and foreign oil companies, â€˜counter Iranâ€™s influenceâ€™ and crucially, â€˜secure US interestsâ€™, the official said.

But while top US representatives including Secretary Rubio have boasted that the deal would â€œreaffirm Iraqâ€™s sovereignty,â€ it could also risk unraveling a delicate sectarian balance in a country already ravaged by decades of US-caused carnage and instability.

ğŸ”´ In 2022, Iraqâ€™s Supreme Court challenged Kurdish interpretation of the ownership and control of oil and gas in Kurdistan, citing constitutional articles saying that national energy resources â€œare owned by all the people of Iraq,â€ across â€œall the regions and governorates,â€ and that Iraq must have a management stake and enjoy sole export rights.

ğŸ”´ Kurdistan has traditionally ignored these arguments, and used technicalities in constitutional terminology to justify control of fields.

ğŸ”´ While the new agreement divides revenues along a structured system, the resumption of the flow of ~230k bpd of crude (and potentially eventually up to 500k bpd) could trigger fresh tensions, particularly amid the involvement of unscrupulous foreign companies looking to maximize profits through illegal side deals.

ğŸ”´ With the US explicitly seeking to â€œweaken Iranâ€™s political influence,â€ the oil agreement also threatens to turn into a geopolitical tinderbox.

ğŸ”´ Kurdistan has already sought to blame â€œpro-Iranian militiasâ€ for a series of oil infrastructure attacks in July (claims militia groups denied). The US, meanwhile, is pressuring Iraq to disarm the militias â€“ despite their critical role in crushing ISIS and stabilizing the country between 2015-2017.

ğŸš¨ Netanyahu's deliberate strategy to bolster Hamas ğŸ’¥ğŸ’¥ğŸ’¥

ğŸ‘‰ For years, Netanyahu deliberately allowed Qatar to funnel money, including in suitcases of cash, directly to Hamas in Gaza, John Oliver reveals.

Key details:

ğŸ”´ The objective was to keep Hamas in power to weaken its rival, the Palestinian Authority, thereby creating a divided Palestinian leadership.

ğŸ”´ He openly argued that a strong Hamas was beneficial because it lessened pressure on him to negotiate for a Palestinian state.

ğŸ”´ This money was used by Hamas to build its military infrastructure, including tunnels and rockets, which are now being used against Israel.

ğŸ”´ Netanyahu ignored specific warnings from Israel's internal security chief about the growing threat from Hamas, believing the group had been "deterred."

items.title: ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡ºğŸ’¥ Russiaâ€™s night strike strategy: attacks on inf...
items.content_text:
ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡ºğŸ’¥ Russiaâ€™s night strike strategy: attacks on infrastructure are crippling Ukraineâ€™s war economy

Russiaâ€™s missile and drone campaign continues to intensify, with the Russian MoD reporting Friday that overnight strikes targeted Ukrainian â€œmilitary-industrial complex enterprises and gas and energy infrastructure facilities that supported their operations.â€

The MoD did not go into detail, but analysts helped to fill the gaps, with pro-Russian Ukrainian politician Oleg Tsarevâ€™s sources indicating Russia used ~300 long-range drones, 17 cruise and 7 ballistic missiles

Targets included:

ğŸ”´ Logistics and industrial hubs in Poltava and Kharkov regions, including the Shebelinka gas field in Kharkov

ğŸ”´ Gnidyntsy gas processing plant in Chernigov region

ğŸ”´ Southern Machine-Building Plant (formerly Yuzhmash), a massive state-owned aerospace and defense manufacturer in Dnepropetrovsk

ğŸ”´ power substations in Shostka and Konotop in Sumy region, plus a depot near the Konotop Railcar Repair Plant

ğŸ”´ a power substation near Slavutych in Kiev region (along with an enemy base in Bucha)

ğŸ”´ an energy facility in Odessa, and the massive Ukrzaliznytsia rail depot

These kinds of strikes are leaving Ukraineâ€™s MIC without the electricity to build defense orders, and increasingly, without the means to transport domestic and NATO weapons to the front. Theyâ€™ve also had a serious impact on household consumption, with mayors from Lutsk to Ivano-Frankovsk urging residents to prepare for sustained blackouts.

ğŸ“ˆ European media estimate Russian drone and missile strikes increased 36% in September to 5,600+ drones and ~185 missiles.

Military expert and retired military pilot Vladimir Popov says while Russia largely avoided sustained attacks on Ukraineâ€™s power grid up to now for humanitarian reasons, escalating Ukrainian threats are grounds for retaliation.

ğŸ’¬ â€œThis winter will be a test for the Kiev regime â€“ heat and electricity will be increasingly scarce,â€ Popov predicts.
